Description: Most cancers have extensive chromosomal aberrations and prevalent genetic mutations.  What does it mean then that some highly aggressive, lethal cancers have diploid genomes with very few, perhaps even a single, gene mutation?  Simple genomes are prevalent in pediatric cancers but also occur in some cases of adult cancers.  This raises the question, what is the fundamental nature of cancer if genome instability and high mutation loads are not essential?  Also, if cancer promotion is about stimulating DNA damage, why do nearly all oncogenes and tumor suppressors display strong associations with certain cancer types or tissue types?  ‘Simple genome’ cancers are often driven by disruption of transcription factors or chromatin regulators.  What do these mechanisms teach us about the nature of cancer, and about therapeutic vulnerabilities?  The insights from study of these cancers can be great.  For example, while retinoblastoma is a rare pediatric cancer study of this disease not only revealed the importance of the Rb gene and pathway, but also led to the discovery of the role of tumor suppressors in malignancy.  This session will address these key questions and other mechanistic insights into cancer that are now emerging from study of childhood cancers and cancers with simple genomes.  The session is designed to be of interest to a wide audience.
